# Externalities {background-color="#1c4982"}

## What is an Externality?
:::{.nonincremental}
- An **externality** is a side effect of a market transaction—positive or negative—that affects the **well-being of people who are not directly involved** as buyers or sellers.
  - **Negative externality**: imposes costs on others (e.g., air pollution from autos).
  - **Positive externality**: confers benefits on others (e.g., tree planting—amenity value, carbon uptake, habitat).
- Comprehensive analysis must account for **all members of society** (and possibly ecosystems), not only buyers and sellers.

:::

::: callout-tip
**Key idea:** Markets maximize total surplus **only** when *all* marginal costs and benefits are internal to decision‑makers.
:::

## The Market for Automobiles
::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-1.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}

- **Supply curve** ≈ **PMC**: private marginal cost of producing one more unit (labor, materials, energy, etc.).
- **Demand curve** ≈ **PMB**: private marginal benefit (consumers’ willingness‑to‑pay for one more unit).

:::
::::

- **Market equilibrium $(P_{M}, Q_{M})$** is efficient **only if** PMC = SMC and PMB = SMB (i.e., no externalities).


<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.1 (explained)**: For automobiles, demand intersects supply at $(P_{M}, Q_{M})$. With no externalities, this point maximizes total private surplus. -->
<!-- ::: -->


## Accounting for Environmental Costs

- Auto production & use create multiple **negative externalities**: local/regional air pollution, CO₂, water contamination, toxic wastes, habitat loss, road salt runoff, congestion.
- These costs **do not appear** in the private supply curve; hence **market overstates net social benefits** at $(P_{M}, Q_{M})$.
- We must **internalize** external costs to evaluate the market’s true impact.


## EPA Endangerment Finding on GHG Emissions

- **Proposal Date**: July 29, 2025 — EPA formally proposed rescinding the 2009 Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Endangerment Finding ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/proposed-rule-reconsideration-2009-endangerment-finding)).
- **Statutory Impact**: Without the Endangerment Finding, EPA would **lose authority under CAA §202(a)** to regulate GHG emissions from motor vehicles ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/proposed-rule-reconsideration-2009-endangerment-finding); [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulation_of_greenhouse_gases_under_the_Clean_Air_Act)).
  - CAA §202(a) is the EPA’s authority to regulate tailpipe pollution from new vehicles when it threatens public health or welfare.
- **Regulatory Effect**: Proposal includes **removal of GHG standards** for light-, medium-, and heavy-duty vehicles and engines ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/proposed-rule-reconsideration-2009-endangerment-finding)). 
- **What Remains**: Standards for **criteria pollutants, toxic emissions, corporate average fuel economy (CAFE), and labeling** will **not be changed**([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/proposed-rule-reconsideration-2009-endangerment-finding)). 


## EPA Endangerment Finding: Process & Reactions

<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

- **Public Hearing & Comment Period**:
  - Public hearings held August 19–21 (and possibly August 22), 2025.  
  - Comment deadline extended from September 15 to **September 22, 2025** ([Federal Register](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/08/15/2025-15512/reconsideration-of-2009-endangerment-finding-and-greenhouse-gas-vehicle-standards-extension-of); [Office of Advocacy](https://advocacy.sba.gov/2025/08/15/epa-extends-comment-period-for-proposed-repeal-of-greenhouse-gas-endangerment-finding-and-vehicle-emissions-rules/); [Holland & Knight](https://www.hklaw.com/en/insights/publications/2025/08/up-in-the-air-epa-opens-comment-on-repealing-endangerment-finding)).

- **Deregulatory Framing**:
  - The proposal is presented as part of a broader **deregulatory agenda**, hailed as one of the **largest in U.S. history** ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/what-they-are-saying-leaders-praise-epa-launching-largest-deregulatory-action-us)).
  - EPA claims the repeal could save Americans **$54 billion annually** and **$170 billion for small businesses** ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/epa-releases-proposal-rescind-obama-era-endangerment-finding-regulations-paved-way)).

- **Criticisms**:
  - Critics argue the rule **ignores scientific consensus** and is legally weak, potentially dismantling key rules and safeguards designed to protect against climate change ([The Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2025/07/22/endangerment-finding-epa-climate)).

## Valuing Damages
:::{.nonincremental}
- Assign **monetary values** to external harms to build **SMC**:
  - Direct costs (e.g., **water treatment** for contaminated sources).
  - **Health damages** (medical expenses, morbidity, mortality risk).
  - **Aesthetic/amenity** losses (visibility, recreation quality).
  - **Ecosystem** impacts (biodiversity, habitat quality).
- If we assign no value, the market implicitly assigns **zero**—biasing decisions.

:::

::: callout-warning
Valuation aggregates **tangible** and **intangible** impacts; precision is hard, but **order‑of‑magnitude** estimates guide better policy than zeros.
:::



## The Market for Automobiles with Negative Externalities

::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">

  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- **SMC = PMC + EMC**, where **EMC** is the *external marginal cost*.
- Typically, **EMC rises** with output when pollution/congestion intensify.

:::
::::

- **SMC** lies **above** **PMC** by the vertical distance equal to EMC.

# Internalizing Environmental Costs {background-color="#1c4982"}

## Fixing the Inefficiency: Pigovian Tax on Automobiles

- **Market failure:** Prices omit pollution damages ⇒ production **beyond $Q^{*}$** is socially undesirable.
- **Goal:** Get the price **“right”** by **internalizing** external costs so they enter consumer/producer decisions.
- **Tool — Pigovian tax:** A **per-unit tax \(t\)** on automobile **production or emissions** that makes  
  $$
  \text{PMC} + t = \text{SMC} \quad \text{at } Q^{*}.
  $$
  - Reflects the **Polluter Pays Principle (PPP)**: those causing pollution **pay its external costs**.



## Automobile Market with Pigovian Tax

::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-3.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- Impose a **per‑unit tax** $t$ equal to **EMC at $Q^{*}$**.
- Effect: raises firms’ **private marginal cost** so the *effective* supply coincides with **SMC**.

:::
::::

- New equilibrium: **$(P^{*}, Q^{*})$**—the **socially efficient** outcome.

<!-- - A per-unit tax $t$ is the **vertical gap** between the pre-tax and post-tax cost curves (**$P_0$ to $P^{*}$** in stylized diagrams).   -->

- **Set the right rate**
  - Target the per-unit external damage at $Q^{*}$ so **PMC + $t$ = SMC**.
  

<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.3 (explained):** Supply with tax overlaps SMC; price rises to **P^{*}**, quantity falls to **$Q^{*}$**. Burden shared by consumers (higher price) and producers (lower net‑of‑tax receipts), depending on elasticities. -->
<!-- ::: -->


## Economic Tax Incidence & Elasticities

::::{.nonincremental}
::: callout-note
- A **price elasticity** of demand/supply measures how responsive the quantity demanded/supplied are to price changes.

- An **inelastic** demand/supply ⇒ quantity changes little for a given price change.
  - The more steeper, the less elastic.
  
:::
::::

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-3.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- **Consumer incidence**: the amount of the tax revenue paid by consumers
- **Producer incidence**: the amount of the tax revenue paid by producers

:::
::::



## Who Pays? Economic Incidence & Elasticities


::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-3.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- **Who pays more?** 
  - The **less elastic** (steeper) side of the market bears **more** of the tax.  
:::
::::

- The claim “**firms pass it all on**” is generally **false**; division is **empirical** and depends on elasticities.

## Distributional Concerns

- **Regressivity:** Energy/fuel taxes can burden lower-income households (higher budget share on energy).

- **How to offset (Revenue recycling):**
  - **Lump-sum dividends** (“carbon cash-back”).
  - **Refundable credits** (e.g., energy affordability credit, EITC (earned income tax credits) top-ups).
  - **Targeted transfers** (rural mileage, extreme-climate heating, heating-oil users).
  - **Fixed bill credits / lifeline blocks** for essential usage *(avoid broad per-unit discounts)*.
  - **Just-transition support** for affected workers/communities.

- **Design notes:** Preserve **price signals** (don’t lower per-unit energy prices), make benefits **visible**, and address **equity/political feasibility**

<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- - **Orders of magnitude**: A 2013 estimate put global externalities from **primary industries** (agriculture, fishing, mining, power generation, initial materials processing) near **\$7.3T (~13% of world output)**.  -->
<!-- - World Bank data put **2018 global tax revenues ≈ 15%** of world output.  -->
<!-- - Comprehensive **upstream Pigovian systems** could, in principle, rival existing tax takes—think **tax swaps**, not a literal one-for-one blueprint. -->
<!-- ::: -->



## Don’t tax everything
  - Estimating the “right” tax requires **economics + science**.  
  - For **small externalities**, the revenue may not justify **measurement + admin** costs.  
  - Example: “**shirts**” would imply product-by-product rates (cotton vs. synthetics, dye processes, *organic* vs. *recycled*) → **monumental** complexity.

## Go upstream *(tax near resource extraction)*  
  - Levy at **raw inputs** (e.g., **crude oil**, **cotton**, **ores**, **toxic chemicals**) so costs ripple through prices in proportion to input intensity.  
  - Focus on materials with **widespread ecological damage** (e.g., **fossil fuels**, key minerals, toxics).  
  - Benefits: **far fewer tax points**, lower admin burden, avoids bespoke rates on countless final goods.




## Beyond Taxes: Standards & Mandates

- **Performance/tech standards** (e.g., fuel-efficiency rules) and **mandated controls** (e.g., catalytic converters) can cut emissions **without** directly pricing each unit.  
- Standards often raise **upfront/capital costs**, so that prices can rise (**resemble a tax**), while **energy-efficient equipment** uses less fuel/power, so lifetime bills may fall.
- Useful where **damage estimates are uncertain**, **admin is hard**, or **health/ecological thresholds** justify minimum standards alongside prices.

# Positive Externalities {background-color="#1c4982"}

## Positive Externalities: Market Outcome & Policy

- **Examples**: solar panels (emissions reductions), vaccinations, R&D spillovers, urban trees.

- In an unregulated market, **beneficial spillovers aren’t rewarded** → **underproduction**:
<div style="text-align:center">
  *PMB < SMB  ⇒  $Q_{M}$ <* $Q^{*}$ → **welfare loss**.
</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:15px;"></div>

- **Goal:** internalize social benefits to reach the **efficient level** $Q^{*}$
- **Solar PV example:**
  - Neighbors learn from one household’s installation/operation experience.
  - If one home’s solar panels make more electricity than that home uses during the day, the extra can flow onto the neighborhood.

## The Market for Solar Energy with a Subsidy


::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-5.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- A **producer subsidy** of $s$ per unit **lowers** effective marginal cost (<u>downward supply shift</u>).
- A **consumer subsidy (e.g., tax credit)** **raises** effective willingness‑to‑pay (<u>upward demand shift</u>).

:::
::::

- **Correct subsidy** aligns the market with **$Q^{*}$** where **SMC = SMB**.



<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.5 (explained):** With the subsidy, equilibrium quantity expands to **$Q^{*}$**; price effects differ for producers vs consumers, but the quantity target is the same. -->
<!-- ::: -->

# Welfare Analysis of Externalities {background-color="#1c4982"}

## Welfare Analysis of the Automobile Market


::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-6.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- **Consumer Surplus (CS):** Area **under demand** and **above price**.
- **Producer Surplus (PS):** Area **above supply (PMC)** and **below price**.

:::
::::

- Without externalities, equilibrium maximizes **CS + PS**.



<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.6 (explained):** At $(P_{M}, Q_{M})$, CS = area **A**; PS = area **B**. -->
<!-- ::: -->

## Welfare Analysis of the Automobile Market
### With Pigouvian Tax

<div style="text-align: center; width: 45%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-3-cs-ps-tr-ex-net.jpg" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>

With such a negative externality, true **social welfare (SW)** is:
  $$
  \begin{align}
  &\quad\;\; (\text{SW})\,=\, (\text{CS} + \text{PS} + \text{Tax Revenue}) \,-\, (\text{External Cost}).
  \end{align}
  $$
  
- **Pigovian Tax Improves Welfare**: welfare **rises by C** relative to the unregulated outcome.

## Optimal Pollution
- **Zero pollution** generally implies **zero production**; instead, economists seek the **efficient** (not necessarily zero) level of pollution given current <u>*technology*</u> and <u>*preferences*</u>.
  - The **Pigovian tax** yields **optimal (residual) pollution**—the remaining damages at **$Q^{*}$**.
- **Caveat**: If demand shifts right (e.g., autos more valued), the **efficient** pollution level can rise—raising questions about **science‑based caps** vs. **pure efficiency**.

::: callout-note
- **Preferences** (what people want—<u>demand</u>) and **technology** (what/how much outputs can be produced from scarce inputs—<u>supply</u>), given **endowments** (initial resources) and **prices**, jointly determine **market equilibrium** and **welfare**, as **consumers maximize utility** and **firms maximize profit**.
- Policy practice often sets **health‑based standards** (e.g., the Clean Air Act) and then uses market instruments to **achieve** those standards cost‑effectively.
:::

## Tax Incidence

  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-3-tax-revenue.jpg" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>


<span style="color:green">**Tax Revenue**</span>: $t \times Q^{*}$

**Tax incidence**: The division of the tax burden between consumers and producers, determined by the relative elasticities of demand and supply.


## Tax Incidence

<div style="text-align: center; width: 45%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-3-ci-pi.jpg" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

<span style="color:blue">**Consumer incidence**</span>: The amount to which **CS** decreases, measured over quantities from $0$ to $Q^{*}$ $\;\rightarrow\;$ Tax falls on *consumers*, who pay $P^{*} - P_{M}$ *more* per unit.

<span style="color:red">**Producer incidence**</span>: The amount to which **PS** decreases, measured over quantities from $0$ to $Q^{*}$ $\;\rightarrow\;$ Tax falls on *producers*, who receive $P_{M} - P_{0}$ *less* per unit.


## Tax Incidence: Ordinary vs. Pigouvian Tax

<div style="display:block; margin:-20px;"></div>


:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
#### Ordinary Tax (in a Competitive Market)
- **Incidence**:  
  - <span style="color:blue">Consumers</span> pay higher price ($P^{*} - P_{M}$).  
  - <span style="color:red">Producers</span> receive lower price ($P_{M} - P_{0}$).  
- **Welfare effect**:  
  - Creates **deadweight loss (DWL)**.  
  - Total surplus falls.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
#### Pigouvian Tax
- **Incidence**:  
  - <span style="color:blue">Consumers</span> and <span style="color:red">Producers</span> still share burden depending on elasticities.  
- **Welfare effect**:  
  - **Internalizes externality** (e.g., pollution).  
  - Reduces overproduction: $Q_{M} \rightarrow Q^{*}$.  
  - Improves **social welfare** by offsetting external damages.
:::

::::
